ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to analyze different texts and connect them throughout time. I also gained several valuable writing skills.
I learned how to do more close text analysis
Much deeper understanding of American literary figures and their work

In this course, I learned about the important discourses and points of literary theory in American Literature. The course expanded my knowledge of the historical discourses and ideologies surrounding specific works of American Literature to better understand the evolution and creation of these works.
Learned how to analyze texts and discuss them in seminar type setting.

- seeing themes across texts
- synthesizing themes through written work 
- presenting

I gained an improved understanding of themes and trends in American Literature. The course was heavy on intertextuality which gave students insight into the vast and connected inspiration of the authors. Students had the chance to meet with one of the authors and discuss their novel as well as the process of writing in general which was both exciting and enlightening.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think the strengths lie in the robust discussions my class was able to have surrounding the texts. I was able to deeply appreciate each piece of literature we read, and better evaluate in not only in the context of its time period, but in the context of all literature.

Weakness: I think the course is a little ambitious and trying to cover a very wide range of literature, I wouldve appreciated more time to go deeper into the individual texts

Strengths: the diversity and scope of literature, we engaged with was very eye-opening
Only strengths; Professor Williams is brilliant and engaging. Seminar is enjoyable, and the essay prompts are quirky and thought-provoking.

The strength of this course is that there was a lot of room for interpretation, class discussion, and critical thinking. The novels we discussed ranged from a wide variety of voices in American literature that come from different backgrounds, races, and periods, which I felt made for a very holistic conversation about American Literature. I really enjoyed how the works ranged from old forks from the 19th century that flowed into contemporary works that brought up interesting conversations and connections.

Strengths: engaging discussions, understanding professor, welcoming class environment
Weaknesses: Sometimes, the discussions were not entirely about the text. But overall, no other weaknesses.
- while the student presentations were interesting, toward the end of the course, i really missed just getting to discuss our texts

The stength was definitely the selected reading list. The novels, poems, and short stories were engaging, versatile, and gave a comprehensive understanding of American literature for the short amount of time we had in the term. I think the class time could have been spent better. Although there were very productive class discussions, they were often focused on very small sections of the text or even singular words. I would have preferred a broader discussion that was led by what students found interesting. I think this would have increased class engagement as well.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would definitely recommend this course to another student!! Its a great way to get familiar with different kinds of American literature.
I would recommend this course to anyone who is interested in learning more about American literature in a class that has a relatively lighter workload.
ABSOLUTELY!!! One of my favorite classes Ive taken at Yale!
Definitely!!! Amazing Professor and wonderful material.

english major requirement. 

I'd recommend this course with Prof Williams specifically because the essay prompts were interesting, not just the run-of-the-mill "place text A in conversation with text B." which makes it a much more enjoyable experience. 

on the other hand Williams was constantly behind on discussion, grading, and releasing prompts. Our we'd be discussing readings 2-3 days after the syllabus scheduled, and we'd never really catch up. often we talked about something completely separate from the readings. there were also multiple times that Williams brought up the same slides, and gave the same analysis/lecture style thing as if he hadn't done it before. this happened with connections to the Odyssey and palimpsests, which would first be brought up during the Narrative of the life of Frederick Douglass and Moby-Dick, only to then be brought up again a month later, with the same explanation, almost word for word, for 15 minutes.   

the feedback /commentary on the essays was little to none, seemed like it was rushed, and not indicative of a writing credit. So, if you're maybe a freshman looking to improve your writing through a WR credit, this isn't the spot. but if you're an English major, this is a great foundation course to take. especially after coming off of 126's very boring essay prompts. 

either way, if you're going to take 127 take it with john. 

(he's also in a band, so obviously you'll have entertaining conversations with your classmates when they inevitably find out he's in a band)

I would recommend this course to other students if they are genuinely interested in studying literature and understanding literary theory. This is a great course for aspiring writers, and English and Comparative Literature majors. The discussions surrounding these canonical works truly changed my perspective on American Literature and helped me to become a better reader.
I would! I got a great introduction to American literature and even got to talk to the writer of one of our books! Great experience!
yes - enjoyable for english major requirement

I would definitely recommend this course to students who are interested in delving further into American literature but am not sure I would give it as a broad recommendation as the course feels fairly specific.
